clues.text:
Goal,
swimsuit

Rocks,
brooms

Hoops,
ribbons
Bindings & a tube with 22-foot-high walls

Horse,
epee
There's a silent "B" in this adjective meaning mysterious & faint, like the Mona Lisa's smile
This optical device that uses mirrors & colored glass gets its name partly from the Greek for "beautiful"
This portmanteau word for a women's 2-piece bathing suit that provides more coverage than a bikini dates to 1985
Tilt, prejudice & diagonal are synonyms of this 4-letter word
Geometry has cool words like rhombus & this one for a quadrilateral with only 2 parallel sides
Associated with a group of poets, this scenic area gets its name from multiple bodies of water including Derwent Water
Donegall Square is in the heart of this capital city
Doing something redundant is like "carrying coals" to this city, formerly a coal-mining center
In 1910 6 pottery-making towns got together & formed what became Stoke-on-this river
Lewis & Harris is the largest of the Scottish islands known as the Outer these
"How Did I Get Here?" is an interdimensional game show on the animated series named for this pair
On an episode of the cartoon called "The Real" this group, Ray & Winston play "Race the Devil"; Venkman is in the audience
A sequel to this mind-bending 1975 movie musical, "Shock Treatment" finds Brad & Janet as contestants on "Marriage Maze"
In this 1987 film Arnold Schwarzenegger tries to survive a public execution game show
"What Do Kids Know?" is a game show in this Paul Thomas Anderson film with a tree for a title
Anaxagoras pointed out that "The descent to" this Greek underworld "is the same from every place"
From this female poet: "The Moon has set, and the Pleiades; it is midnight, and time passes, and I sleep alone"
Lao-tzu said, "I have just three things to teach", not "Love! Valour!" This! but "simplicity, patience" & this
Augustus Caesar said he "found Rome a city of bricks and left it a city of" this, which was much nicer!
In one of his famous comedies, he asked, "Haven't you sometimes seen a cloud that looked like a Centaur?"
This bestselling novel by Laura Esquivel was published in Spanish as "Como agua para chocolate"
In a novel by Matt Haig, infinite books line the shelves of "The Midnight" this title place; most offer another story of reality
Sergio D'Angelo sneaked this story of Yuri & Lara out of the USSR & it became a bestseller
Madeline Miller had bestsellers with "Circe" & "The Song of" him
This 1956 book about a politician in his final campaign became a phrase meaning any fine or brave farewell performance
The first half of this greeting card company's name is the family that founded it in 1910
In 2006 the new CEO of this beverage company was August IV, great-great-grandson of co-founder Adolphus
The Haas family enjoyed a combined net worth of $4.7 billion after a 2019 I.P.O. of this California-based jeans company
Turns out people like candy! In 2019, 6 members of this family whose co. makes Snickers & M&M's were on the Forbes 400
The PiÃ«ch-Porsche family has the largest stake in this automaker that owns Audi, & yes, Porsche
The ACPT is the American tournament for these cruciverbalist challenges
This org.'s first "King of the Ring" tournament saw the Magnificent Muraco defeat the Iron Sheik in the final
In 1985 the NCAA men's "March Madness" basketball tournament expanded to this many teams
Just like soccer, in July 2019 this video game had a World Cup, in NYC's Arthur Ashe Stadium with a $3 million grand prize
In 1851 the first international tournament of this game was held in London, with Adolf Anderssen crowned champion
This 6-letter internally rhyming word means tiny
We're makin' this interjection, an expression of massive delight, like wahoo!
Drifting independently heedless of rules, like Bob Dylan in a '63 album title
Job title of an Old West owner of an establishment such as the Bucket of Blood in Nevada
This transparent feature first debuted for Ford on the 1973 Lincoln Continental Mark IV
The gentlefolk of a society
It partners with "Fugue" in the title of a Bach composition
Fans of vintage stuff covet old unsold items classed as this inventory with a "mortal" name
Labs & hospitals sterilize equipment in these pressure cookers
The name of this cloud layer means "high heap"
In "The Moth and the Mountain", the Moth is a Gipsy Moth, one of these Maurice Wilson used to get to Everest in the 1930s
"The Great Secret" tells how a military doctor found cancer-fighting uses in this type of poison gas
In Isabel Wilkerson's book, this 5-letter title doesn't refer to India's social hierarchy, but America's
"Islamic Empires" follows the rise of the religion from its birth in Mecca to modern cities like Doha in this country
"Sicily '43" sees the Allied invasion of the island through the eyes of men like Patton & this British field marshal
This short jacket shares its name with a movement of the shoulders
How about a blazer in this "fishy" pattern with alternating V shapes
The song "Surfin' U.S.A." mentions these sandals with a Mexican Spanish name
Similar to a jumpsuit, a one-piece women's garment combining a short-sleeve top & loose shorts has this lively name
The soft underfur of a Tibetan goat gives this cashmere shawl its name, which is partly derived from Urdu

rounds.text: A Radical Republican championed this 1875 act but the Supreme Court struck it down in 1883; a new version was passed 81 years later
